title: diagnostics: very confusing error when calling Vec::from_iter() on &[1].iter()

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: An issue proposing an enhancement or a PR with one.

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

```rust
    let iter = &[1,2,3].into_iter();
    let v: Vec<&i32> = Vec::from_iter(iter);
```

I expected to see this happen:
I was thinking: I convert an &[array] into an iterator and then into a Vector.
This did not work out so well, the error message just seemed to tell me that my `.into_iter()` did not result in an iterator...?? :confused: 


Instead, this happened: 
````
   Compiling fromiter v0.1.0 (/tmp/fromiter)
error[E0277]: `&std::slice::Iter<'_, {integer}>` is not an iterator
 --> src/main.rs:5:39
  |
5 |     let v: Vec<&i32> = Vec::from_iter(iter);
  |                                       ^^^^ `&std::slice::Iter<'_, {integer}>` is not an iterator
  |
  = help: the trait `Iterator` is not implemented for `&std::slice::Iter<'_, {integer}>`
  = note: required because of the requirements on the impl of `IntoIterator` for `&std::slice::Iter<'_, {integer}>`
  = note: required by `from_iter`

error: aborting due to previous error

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0277`.
error: could not compile `fromiter`

To learn more, run the command again with --verbose.
````

It turned out that I had to remove the reference from the front of the array like this
````rust
    let iter = [1,2,3].into_iter();
    let v: Vec<&i32> = Vec::from_iter(iter);
````
Would be great if rustc could suggest "you could try removing the borrow here".

### Meta
<!--
If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->

`rustc --version --verbose`:
